title: Four-Day Work Week Intensity Compression
context: Companies adopt four-day work weeks promising better work-life balance and equal productivity. Early trials show promising results — employees report higher satisfaction and output per hour increases. But the mechanism behind maintaining output in fewer hours is often intensity compression: meetings get shorter but more packed, breaks disappear, lunch becomes optional, and the social fabric of work erodes. Employees trade one form of burnout (long hours) for another (relentless intensity). The extra day off becomes recovery from the compressed four days rather than genuine leisure.
hypothesis: Four-day work weeks improve work-life balance while maintaining productivity.

dontIf: Your work requires significant mentoring, collaboration, or creative ideation time
You plan to maintain the same output targets in fewer hours without process changes
ifYouMust: Reduce scope and output expectations proportionally, not just hours
Protect informal interaction time — schedule it if necessary
Monitor intensity metrics (meeting density, break frequency) not just output
